title: Hosea Chapter 13 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Hosea chapter 13 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Hosea Chapter 13 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Hosea Chapter 13.

questions.question: According to Hosea 13:4, who is the only saviour?
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD thy God
questions.explanation: Hosea 13:4 states, 'there is no saviour beside me,' referring to the LORD thy God.

questions.question: What did Ephraim do when he offended in Baal according to Hosea 13:1?
questions.correctAnswer: He died
questions.explanation: Hosea 13:1 says, 'but when he offended in Baal, he died.'

questions.question: What image do the people kiss according to Hosea 13:2?
questions.correctAnswer: Calves
questions.explanation: Hosea 13:2 mentions, 'Let the men that sacrifice kiss the calves.'

questions.question: How does Hosea describe Ephraim's fate in Hosea 13:3?
options: As the morning cloud and early dew that passeth away
questions.correctAnswer: As the morning cloud and early dew that passeth away
questions.explanation: Hosea 13:3 compares Ephraim to 'the morning cloud, and as the early dew that passeth away.'

questions.question: Where did God know Ephraim according to Hosea 13:5?
questions.correctAnswer: In the wilderness
questions.explanation: Hosea 13:5 says, 'I did know thee in the wilderness, in the land of great drought.'

questions.question: What animal does God say He will be to Ephraim in Hosea 13:7?
questions.correctAnswer: A lion
questions.explanation: Hosea 13:7 states, 'I will be unto them as a lion.'

questions.question: Complete the phrase from Hosea 13:14: 'I will ransom them from the power of the ______;'
questions.correctAnswer: grave
questions.explanation: Hosea 13:14 declares, 'I will ransom them from the power of the grave.'

questions.question: True or False: According to Hosea 13:11, God gave a king in His anger and took him away in His wrath.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Hosea 13:11 says, 'I gave thee a king in mine anger, and took him away in my wrath.'

questions.question: According to Hosea 13:6, what caused Ephraim to forget God?
options: They were filled according to their pasture
questions.correctAnswer: Both of the above
questions.explanation: Hosea 13:6 says, 'According to their pasture, so were they filled; ... therefore have they forgotten me.'

questions.question: What will happen to Samaria according to Hosea 13:16?
questions.correctAnswer: It shall become desolate
questions.explanation: Hosea 13:16 states, 'Samaria shall become desolate; for she hath rebelled against her God.'

questions.question: According to Hosea 13:9, where is Israel's help?
questions.correctAnswer: In God
questions.explanation: Hosea 13:9 says, 'but in me is thine help,' referring to God.

questions.question: True or False: Hosea 13:8 compares God's judgment to a bear bereaved of her whelps.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Hosea 13:8 states, 'I will meet them as a bear that is bereaved of her whelps.'

questions.question: What kind of wind is mentioned in Hosea 13:15?
questions.correctAnswer: East wind
questions.explanation: Hosea 13:15 says, 'Though he be fruitful ... an east wind shall come, the wind of the LORD shall come up from the wilderness.'

questions.question: According to Hosea 13:12, what is bound up and hidden?
questions.correctAnswer: The iniquity of Ephraim
questions.explanation: Hosea 13:12 says, 'The iniquity of Ephraim is bound up; his sin is hid.'

questions.question: True or False: Hosea 13:10 says God will be Israel's king and questions who else can save.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Hosea 13:10 reads, 'I will be thy king: where is any other that may save thee in all thy cities?'

medium.title: Hosea Chapter 13 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Hosea Chapter 13 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with pride and self-exaltation. Based on Hosea 13:1, what biblical truth would you share about humility?
options: Pride leads to downfall and death
Baal is the true source of strength
questions.correctAnswer: Pride leads to downfall and death
questions.explanation: Hosea 13:1 shows that Ephraim exalted himself but died when he offended in Baal, teaching that pride leads to destruction. This is supported by verses 6 and 9 which show forgetting God leads to ruin.

questions.question: How does Hosea 13:2 warn us about idolatry in relation to obedience and faith?
options: Idols are man-made and lead people away from God
Craftsmen make idols by God's command
questions.correctAnswer: Idols are man-made and lead people away from God
questions.explanation: Verse 2 highlights that idols are molten images made by craftsmen and represent human understanding, leading people to sin more and stray from God’s truth, as seen also in verses 6 and 12.

questions.question: What does Hosea 13:3 teach about the temporary nature of worldly things and how should that influence Christian contentment?
options: Worldly things are fleeting like morning dew
questions.correctAnswer: Worldly things are fleeting like morning dew
questions.explanation: Verse 3 compares Ephraim to morning cloud and early dew which pass away quickly, reminding believers to remain humble and content with eternal things, supported by verses 6 and 15.

questions.question: A believer doubts if God alone is the savior. According to Hosea 13:4, what truth can you share about God's uniqueness?
options: There is no savior beside the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: There is no savior beside the LORD
questions.explanation: Verse 4 clearly states God alone is the LORD and savior, emphasizing exclusive trust in Him, which is reinforced by verse 9's message of finding help only in God.

questions.question: How does Hosea 13:5 encourage believers to remember God's past faithfulness to strengthen their trust in Him during trials?
options: God knew them in the wilderness during drought
God abandoned them in the desert
Only kings can help in drought
questions.correctAnswer: God knew them in the wilderness during drought
questions.explanation: Verse 5 reminds believers of God's intimate knowledge and provision during hard times, encouraging trust and perseverance as seen also in verses 9 and 14.

questions.question: What lesson about forgetting God and consequences can we learn from Hosea 13:6?
options: Being satisfied leads to forgetting God and downfall
Being filled means God is honored
Forgetfulness of God has no effect
questions.correctAnswer: Being satisfied leads to forgetting God and downfall
questions.explanation: Verse 6 shows that after being filled according to their pasture, their hearts were exalted and they forgot God, which connects to consequences described in verses 7 and 8.

questions.question: In Hosea 13:7-8, God compares His judgment to wild animals. How can this imagery teach us about God’s holiness and justice?
options: God’s judgment is fierce and unavoidable against sin
God is weak and easily pacified
questions.correctAnswer: God’s judgment is fierce and unavoidable against sin
questions.explanation: These verses use strong imagery of lions, leopards, and bears to show God’s righteous judgment on those who turn from Him, highlighting the seriousness of sin.

questions.question: True or False: Hosea 13:9 teaches that even though Israel has destroyed itself, God remains their source of help.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 9 states that despite Israel’s self-destruction, help is found in God alone, encouraging believers to rely on Him in all circumstances.

questions.question: What does Hosea 13:10-11 reveal about God's response to Israel's request for a king?
options: God gave a king in anger and removed him in wrath
God refused to give a king
Kings save Israel more than God
questions.correctAnswer: God gave a king in anger and removed him in wrath
questions.explanation: Verses 10-11 show that God gave Israel a king as a consequence of their demand, but removed him in anger, teaching trust in God’s leadership over human rulers.

questions.question: How does Hosea 13:12 describe the condition of Ephraim’s sin, and what does that teach about hidden sin?
options: Ephraim’s sin is bound up and hidden, but still destructive
Ephraim’s sin is obvious and forgiven
Sin is only harmful if exposed
questions.correctAnswer: Ephraim’s sin is bound up and hidden, but still destructive
questions.explanation: Verse 12 indicates the seriousness of sin even when concealed, reminding believers to confess and repent rather than hide sin, as connected to verses 6 and 8.

questions.question: A believer faces consequences from unwise choices. What warning does Hosea 13:13 give about foolishness and timing?
options: The unwise son should not delay in the place of childbirth
questions.correctAnswer: The unwise son should not delay in the place of childbirth
questions.explanation: Verse 13 uses the metaphor of labor pains to show that foolishness brings inevitable suffering and that delay or wrong timing worsens consequences.

questions.question: Based on Hosea 13:14, what hope can you share with someone overwhelmed by death and despair?
options: God promises to ransom and redeem from death
questions.correctAnswer: God promises to ransom and redeem from death
questions.explanation: Verse 14 declares God’s power to overcome death and the grave, offering hope and redemption, which encourages believers facing trials and loss.

questions.question: True or False: Hosea 13:15 teaches that even though Ephraim will be fruitful, God's judgment will dry up their blessings.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 15 shows that despite fruitfulness, an east wind from the Lord will dry up Ephraim’s springs and treasures, illustrating consequences of rebellion.

questions.question: How does Hosea 13:16 warn about the results of rebellion and what practical counsel does it offer for family life?
options: Rebellion leads to desolation and suffering for families
Children are safe regardless of rebellion
questions.correctAnswer: Rebellion leads to desolation and suffering for families
questions.explanation: Verse 16 warns that Samaria’s rebellion results in desolation and severe judgment affecting even infants and pregnant women, underscoring the need for faithfulness in family and community.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Hosea 13:4 says, 'Yet I am the LORD thy God from the land of ________, and thou shalt know no god but me.'
questions.correctAnswer: Egypt
questions.explanation: Verse 4 identifies God as the LORD from the land of Egypt, emphasizing His role as deliverer and the only true God to be known and trusted.

hard.title: Hosea Chapter 13 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Hosea Chapter 13.

questions.question: In Hosea 13:4, God declares He is the LORD from the land of Egypt and the only savior. Which Old Testament event does this declaration allude to, emphasizing God's uniqueness as savior?
questions.correctAnswer: The Exodus from Egypt
questions.explanation: Hosea 13:4 references God as the LORD from the land of Egypt, alluding to the Exodus where God delivered Israel, emphasizing there is no savior besides Him.

questions.question: Hosea 13:2 describes Ephraim making molten images and idols. What is the significance of the phrase 'Let the men that sacrifice kiss the calves' in the context of ancient Israelite idolatry?
options: It mimics the worship of the golden calf in Exodus
It refers to a ritual of blessing animals
It describes a New Year celebration
questions.correctAnswer: It mimics the worship of the golden calf in Exodus
questions.explanation: The phrase recalls the golden calf worship in Exodus 32, highlighting Israel's repeated idolatry despite God's deliverance.

questions.question: The imagery in Hosea 13:3 compares Ephraim to the morning cloud, early dew, chaff, and smoke. What literary device is primarily used here?
questions.correctAnswer: Simile
questions.explanation: The verse uses similes, indicated by 'as' and 'like,' to emphasize the fleeting and insubstantial nature of Ephraim's existence.

questions.question: According to Hosea 13:7-8, God says He will be like various wild animals to Israel. What is the theological implication of this depiction?
options: God will judge Israel with fierce and relentless justice
God will protect Israel tenderly like a mother bear
God will disguise Himself to teach Israel
God will deliver Israel from wild animals
questions.correctAnswer: God will judge Israel with fierce and relentless justice
questions.explanation: The wild animal imagery conveys God's fierce judgment and the inevitability of punishment for Israel's sins.

questions.question: In Hosea 13:9, the statement 'O Israel, thou hast destroyed thyself; but in me is thine help' presents a paradox. What does this paradox reveal about the relationship between Israel and God?
options: Despite Israel's self-destructive sin, God remains their only source of salvation
Israel is completely abandoned by God due to their sin
Israel's destruction is final and irreversible
questions.correctAnswer: Despite Israel's self-destructive sin, God remains their only source of salvation
questions.explanation: The verse highlights God's enduring role as savior even when Israel's actions lead to self-destruction.

questions.question: Hosea 13:10 states, 'I will be thy king: where is any other that may save thee in all thy cities?' How does this contrast with Israel's demand in earlier chapters for a human king?
options: God asserts His kingship over Israel in contrast to their desire for human rulers
God agrees to Israel's request for a king
God appoints a foreign king to rule Israel
God suggests they worship other gods
questions.correctAnswer: God asserts His kingship over Israel in contrast to their desire for human rulers
questions.explanation: This verse reflects God's rejection of Israel's request for a human king (see 1 Samuel 8), affirming His sovereignty as the true king.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'I gave thee a king in mine anger, and took him away in my wrath' in Hosea 13:11 foreshadow in Israel's history?
options: The rise and fall of King Jeroboam
The establishment of the Davidic dynasty
questions.correctAnswer: The rise and fall of King Jeroboam
questions.explanation: This likely refers to God raising a king (Jeroboam) in anger who ultimately led Israel to sin and was removed in God's wrath.

questions.question: In Hosea 13:12, 'The iniquity of Ephraim is bound up; his sin is hid.' What Hebrew concept does this expression illustrate regarding sin?
options: The idea that sin is accumulated and stored up for judgment
questions.correctAnswer: The idea that sin is accumulated and stored up for judgment
questions.explanation: The phrase suggests sins are accumulated and concealed but will result in inevitable judgment.

questions.question: Hosea 13:14 contains a rare declaration of victory over death and the grave. Which New Testament passage echoes this theme of resurrection and victory?
questions.correctAnswer: 1 Corinthians 15:54-55
questions.explanation: Paul's passage about death being swallowed up in victory echoes Hosea's triumphant words over death and the grave.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'repentance shall be hid from mine eyes' in Hosea 13:14 in terms of divine judgment?
options: God will no longer accept repentance because judgment is certain
God will forgive all sins freely
God will ignore Israel's sins indefinitely
God will hide repentance from sinners
questions.correctAnswer: God will no longer accept repentance because judgment is certain
questions.explanation: This phrase indicates that God's patience has ended and repentance will no longer avert judgment.

questions.question: Hosea 13:15 uses the metaphor of an east wind drying the spring and fountain. In the ancient Near Eastern context, what does the east wind typically symbolize?
options: A destructive force bringing drought and judgment
A symbol of peace and prosperity
questions.correctAnswer: A destructive force bringing drought and judgment
questions.explanation: The east wind in the ANE often signified harsh, hot winds that brought devastation and symbolize God's judgment here.

questions.question: In Hosea 13:16, the graphic description of infants dashed and women with child ripped up serves what rhetorical purpose?
options: To shock the audience and emphasize the severity of Samaria's judgment
To describe a historical battle victory
To offer comfort to the people
To predict a future peaceful era
questions.correctAnswer: To shock the audience and emphasize the severity of Samaria's judgment
questions.explanation: The vivid imagery underscores the harsh consequences of rebellion against God, evoking horror and urgency.

questions.question: True or False: Hosea 13:6 indicates that Israel's prosperity led them to exalt their hearts and forget God.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Hosea 13:6 explicitly links Israel's satisfaction from pasture with their heart being exalted, leading to forgetfulness of God.

questions.question: True or False: Hosea 13:5 emphasizes God's knowledge of Israel only after they entered the Promised Land.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Hosea 13:5 states God knew Israel in the wilderness, before entering the Promised Land, highlighting His longstanding relationship.

questions.question: Which animal imagery in Hosea 13:8 symbolizes God's fierce and maternal anger simultaneously?
options: A bear bereaved of her whelps
A lion roaring in the jungle
questions.correctAnswer: A bear bereaved of her whelps
questions.explanation: The 'bear bereaved of her whelps' conveys both fierce maternal protectiveness and destructive anger, illustrating God's judgment.

theological.title: Hosea Chapter 13 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Hosea Chapter 13 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Hosea 13:4, what exclusive claim does God make about Himself?
options: There is no savior beside me
I am the creator of heaven and earth
I am the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob
I will never forsake my people
questions.correctAnswer: There is no savior beside me
questions.explanation: Hosea 13:4 declares God's exclusive identity as the only God and Savior, affirming monotheism and salvation found only in Him. This is consistent with Isaiah 43:11, John 14:6, Deuteronomy 4:35, and Acts 4:12.

questions.question: What metaphor does God use in Hosea 13:7-8 to describe His judgment on Israel?
options: A lion, a leopard, and a bear
A sharp sword and burning furnace
questions.correctAnswer: A lion, a leopard, and a bear
questions.explanation: God describes His judgment as fierce and relentless like predatory animals to emphasize the severity of Israel's sin and coming punishment, similar to imagery in Amos 3:8, Jeremiah 5:6, and Revelation 13:2.

questions.question: What reason does Hosea 13:6 give for Israel forgetting God?
options: Their hearts were exalted because they were filled
They were led astray by false prophets
They were oppressed by foreign nations
questions.correctAnswer: Their hearts were exalted because they were filled
questions.explanation: The verse connects prosperity and self-satisfaction with spiritual pride, causing Israel to forget God, paralleling Proverbs 16:18, Deuteronomy 8:11, Luke 21:34, and James 1:14-15.

questions.question: In Hosea 13:14, what is God's declared power over death and the grave?
options: God will ransom and redeem from death and destroy the grave
God will abandon the dead to their fate
God will ignore the power of death
God will grant immortality to all
questions.correctAnswer: God will ransom and redeem from death and destroy the grave
questions.explanation: This verse reveals God's sovereignty over death, promising redemption and victory over the grave, a theme echoed in Psalm 49:15, Isaiah 25:8, 1 Corinthians 15:54-55, and Revelation 20:14.

questions.question: What consequence is described in Hosea 13:16 for Samaria's rebellion against God?
options: Desolation and violent death including infants and pregnant women
Exile to foreign lands without hope of return
A plague that will consume the city
questions.correctAnswer: Desolation and violent death including infants and pregnant women
questions.explanation: The verse describes a harsh judgment due to rebellion, emphasizing the severity of divine justice, consistent with warnings in Jeremiah 19:9, 2 Kings 6:33, Isaiah 13:16, and Lamentations 2:20.

questions.question: What does Hosea 13:10 say about God’s kingship and Israel’s request for human rulers?
options: God will be their king and questions who else can save them
God will forsake them because they wanted a king
God will grant their request for a king without judgment
God will punish them by removing all their judges
questions.correctAnswer: God will be their king and questions who else can save them
questions.explanation: The verse affirms God's ultimate kingship and salvation, challenging the wisdom of seeking human rulers instead, paralleling 1 Samuel 8:7, Psalm 47:7, Isaiah 33:22, and Revelation 19:16.

questions.question: What is the nature of Ephraim’s sin as described in Hosea 13:2?
options: Idolatry involving molten images and calves
Murder and oppression of the poor
Blasphemy against the name of God
questions.correctAnswer: Idolatry involving molten images and calves
questions.explanation: The verse shows Ephraim's continual sin of idolatry by crafting silver idols and worshipping calves, consistent with Exodus 32:4, Judges 6:25-30, 1 Kings 12:28, and Psalm 106:19-20.

questions.question: According to Hosea 13:11, how did God respond to Israel’s request for a king?
options: God gave a king in anger and took him away in wrath
God ignored their request and left them without a king
God granted their request with blessings
God sent a prophet instead of a king
questions.correctAnswer: God gave a king in anger and took him away in wrath
questions.explanation: The verse reveals God's displeasure over Israel’s demand for a king, indicating judgment through the rise and fall of their kings, aligning with 1 Samuel 12:12, Judges 8:23, Psalm 2:10-12, and Jeremiah 21:7.

questions.question: What does Hosea 13:1 indicate happened to Ephraim when he offended in Baal?
questions.correctAnswer: He died
questions.explanation: The verse connects Ephraim’s offense in Baal worship with death, illustrating the fatal consequences of idolatry, consistent with Romans 6:23, Galatians 6:8, Ezekiel 18:4, and James 1:15.

questions.question: How does Hosea 13:3 describe the fate of Israel?
options: Like a morning cloud, early dew, chaff driven by the whirlwind, and smoke out of the chimney
Like a mighty tree that stands forever
Like a mountain unshaken by storms
Like a river flowing to the sea
questions.correctAnswer: Like a morning cloud, early dew, chaff driven by the whirlwind, and smoke out of the chimney
questions.explanation: This imagery illustrates Israel’s fleeting and unstable existence due to judgment, echoing Job 7:6, Psalm 102:3, Isaiah 40:7, and James 4:14.

questions.question: What is implied about Israel’s spiritual condition in Hosea 13:12?
options: Their iniquity and sin are hidden and bound up
Their righteousness is evident to all
questions.correctAnswer: Their iniquity and sin are hidden and bound up
questions.explanation: The verse suggests Israel’s sins are deeply entrenched and concealed, reflecting a hardened heart, consistent with Jeremiah 17:9, Romans 1:18, Psalm 51:6, and Hebrews 3:13.

questions.question: What does Hosea 13:9 affirm despite Israel’s self-destruction?
questions.correctAnswer: In God is their help
questions.explanation: The verse highlights God's enduring role as helper despite Israel's failures, paralleling Psalm 46:1, Isaiah 41:10, Hebrews 13:6, and 2 Corinthians 12:9.

questions.question: What does Hosea 13:15 predict will happen to Israel's prosperity?
options: An east wind from the LORD will dry up their spring and spoil their treasures
They will be blessed with abundant harvests
Their enemies will become their servants
questions.correctAnswer: An east wind from the LORD will dry up their spring and spoil their treasures
questions.explanation: The verse portrays divine judgment as a destructive wind drying up sources of life and wealth, consistent with Jeremiah 18:17, Ezekiel 5:10, Joel 1:4, and Nahum 1:3.

questions.question: What does Hosea 13:5 recall about God's relationship with Israel?
options: God knew Israel in the wilderness during a time of drought
God abandoned Israel in the wilderness
Israel was victorious over their enemies in the wilderness
God punished Israel continuously in the wilderness
questions.correctAnswer: God knew Israel in the wilderness during a time of drought
questions.explanation: This recalls God's intimate and sustaining relationship with Israel during their formative testing period, paralleling Exodus 3:7-8, Deuteronomy 8:2-3, Psalm 78:15-16, and 1 Corinthians 10:4.

questions.question: How does Hosea 13:13 describe Israel's unwise behavior?
options: Like an unwise son who should not linger in the place of childbirth
Like a wise father teaching his children
Like a strong nation prepared for battle
Like a faithful servant obeying the Lord
questions.correctAnswer: Like an unwise son who should not linger in the place of childbirth
questions.explanation: The metaphor portrays Israel’s foolishness and premature suffering, similar to concepts in Proverbs 10:1, Jeremiah 6:14, Hosea 9:13, and Hebrews 5:8-9.
